title: Signing for a loan believing your the co signer and the person you signed for after a verbal agreement to pay never does
question: My uncle (63yrs old) and Aunt (65yrs old ) signed for a loan (believing they were going to be co signeres) for a friend so she could attend nursing school, with a verbal agreement that the friend would pay the loan back when she graduates. Now the friend has been a nurse license active since 2007 and still hasn't paid into the loan. Now my Aunt and Uncle is being harrassed by collectors and with threats that a lein will be placed against there house. what can they do to make this "friend" pay. I have already contacted her and she agreed to start paying but its been 3 months since we spoke and she still hasn't paid
question_tags: Business contracts,Bankruptcy,Judgment lien,Debt,Lien,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Bankruptcy and debt,Fraud,Filing a lawsuit
answers: Unfortunately for your aunt and uncle, there exists a law on the books known as the "statute of frauds" that requires that a promise to pay the debt of another person must be reduced to a writing in order to be enforceable. An oral promise to pay the debt of another is not enforceable. Making things worse, if this loan is a qualified student loan, it is not dischargeable in bankruptcy, except upon a showing that repayment would impose an on reasonable hardship on your aunt and uncle. As far as the threats being made by the collection agency, it has no power to simply impose a lien upon property owned by your aunt and uncle, but it may pursue a lawsuit. If a judgment is obtain in that lawsuit, an abstract of the judgment can be issued and recorded in the office of the County recorder, thereby creating a judgment lien upon any real property owned in the County by your aunt and uncle. Any resolution that may assist your aunt and uncle will probably require the assistance of legal counsel.

You wrote, "My uncle ... and Aunt ... signed for a loan..., with a verbal agreement that the friend would pay the loan back when she graduates. Now the friend has been a nurse license active since 2007 and still hasn't paid."

Comment:
Your uncle and aunt probably have a serious legal impediment to collection with the Statute of Fraud.

I agree with atty Kaufman. No one can just put a lien on someone's house, or any other property for that matter, without first filing and serving a lawsuit and then being sucessfull in getting a judgment. If your relatives are sued by the creditor, they can cross-complain against the friend. Or, they can choose to go ahead and file a suit against the friend now for breach of contract. I know it was a verbal agreement, but still could be enforceable as a contract breach, even a written contract breach if, for example there was any written correspondence with the friend concerning the agreement and through other means. I would suggest consulting with a local civil litigation attorney to review all the facts, pertinent paperwork, etc., to deyermine your options.

The lien threat seems a bit sketchy as I'm not sure they signed their home up as collateral and I'm not sure there is any kind of judgment. That threat may in fact be unlawful. Try Bob Brennan's office in La Crescenta and tell him I said hello.
